ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I think that this course is very valuable for students interested in research of any sort. Although it was a difficult class for me, it was my favorite. Lectures were full of useful information, assignments were instructive, and discussions were lively. I also really appreciated Amity's flexibility in allowing us to modify assignments to further the needs of our individual projects.

Question 1 - - I found the earlier readings most helpful. I didn't find the two books helpful.Question 3 - - Some of the assignments were helpful to my work, but a few (the interview, for example) seemed superfluous the way they are currently set up.Question 6 - - I thought things really slowed down in the second half of the semester. Talking about every single question in class made things tedious and made it hard to stay engaged with such a big group. It also felt like wasted time as we got further and further into the semester and beyond question-generating time.

Question 2: The instructor often went through the slides in the power point very quickly and it was sometimes hard to follow. The information was very good and the instructor is very knowledgeable but the delivery of the lectures was rushed.Question 3: While I thought the outside assignments were useful, I think assignments that are more related to our own research would be useful. I think that assignments relevant to choosing a research topic and making sure that students are on top of finding resources, making contacts, and starting the proposal would be helpful. I also think that assignments related to peer-edits and grant writing would be particularly useful. I felt almost like developing my research project was totally separate from the class and tacked on toward the end. Although we did address our own research throughout it wasn't iterative and therefore I didn't feel as though my project evolved.Question 8: In general I feel as though it is difficult to come into the class not knowing exactly what you want to study- there is not really any room for brainstorming research ideas in the class. I felt like I just randomly picked a research location at the beginning of the semester. I am not sure what the solution to this would be- but this was a challenge for me in the class.
This class helped to guide/support my research process.

my main criticism of this class is that it seems slightly outdatedprofessor dolittle knows the material well, but there should be more material - specifically more recent material.also, i believe there should be some 'field trips/lab assignments' component - perhaps just to the library to work through the search/source processes in real time - this would be very helpful and reinforce some of the individual assignmentsalso this course should be linked to the GIS curriculumall of this said - these critiques arise from the fact that the technology and techniques availability is changing at an incredible pacethe course needs to change - but this is more a simple reality, than any fault of the instructor
The readings were relevant to what we covered in class. The lectures and out-of-class research assignments were really the foundation of the class though.
It would have been helpful to have an earlier deadline for research proposals and possibly to implement a peer review process in class.
It would have been helpful to read other people's proposals before we were assigned to write our own andI would have liked to have more peer-review opportunities.
Professor and TA were down-to-earth, helpful, kind, and thoughtful people. I'm very glad to have made contact with both of them.
Allowing time and care to be spent in putting together proposals.

Class discussions on Thursdays were my favorite part of this course. The body of knowledge that people brought - some of them working on a PhD - was impressive. The debates we had over everything from reading materials to the problems with academia were always interesting.

The Participant observation exercise and the class feedback.Being able to design a small research topic around a particular site of interest and run it was very helpful to see how we feel in the shoes of a researcher. Eventhough I worked with similar goals and under similar circumstances before F&ES, having the time to be introspective about my actions during the experience was very helpful.Class presentations were most helpful to receive feedback and ground my project ideas.

The best thing about this course was being in a group of other students who were all interested in research and developing a project. I wish there had been assignments focused on working with students but I think that I will use the students in this class as a resource throughout my time at FES as I continue to develop and conduct my research.It was also great having a TA who had recently gone through the whole research process and was more than happy to answer any questions about research. She was very knowledgeable and always willing to sit down and talk about anything.
Interacting with other students over their research.
the other students. what drives this course is the conversations and discussions had by students.
The assignments.

getting to share ideas in a symposium style format with our peers (social science MESc candidates). getting to know their patterns and styles, on a personal level as a cohort, will no doubt prove very helpful in the coming yearsthe class was probably larger this year than usual (we had maybe 25 students) so it took a long time to discuss everyone's ideas, comprised a significant percentage of the class - but this was, on the whole, a good thing
Breadth of coverage of methods.
The opportunity to hone my research idea through vetting by the instructor, TF and students, and continuous revisions.
The methods assignments were useful to understanding research process design and class discussions were often engaging.
The TA Jenn Baka was fantastic!!
Workshopping our ideas with other classmates was great and hearing about the challenges people faced were helpful.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The assignments were an absolute waste of time, except for the final assignment. Most of the assignments I completely made up and received excellent grades on them. I stopped doing most of the reading after a few weeks because it was boring and unhelpful (and not necessary to participate in class discussions).

While I enjoyed the course's flexibility, I think it could benefit from having more clearly defined assignment specifications and due dates. Assignments on the syllabus often did not align with what Amity told us in class, which made it difficult to plan, or there were multiple conflicting guidelines for a particular paper, which made it difficult to understand on what basis our assignments were being evaluated.One thing that might be useful to consider: We would often have a lecture on a particular method on Tuesday, and have an assignment on that method due on Thursday, which didn't make much sense to me, because due to time constraints I would have to complete the assignment before lecture. One week when the due date was pushed back, we had the lecture, and then the assignment was due the following week. I think that this was much more helpful for completing the assignment, because we could hear the lecture, then go out and do the assignment.Also, in regards to the question of where the research proposal lecture should go, I think it makes the most sense at the end, but I would put the timeline readings in the first week, so that students can get a better sense of what milestones they should be hitting over the semester.

It needs to be geared more towards getting proposals together - - which is what I thought the point was. It seems to me that the ultimate goal should be researching and submitting to a few funding organizations rather than putting together a hypothetical proposal at the end like a final paper.
A clearer syllabus from the start; there were a lot of revisions as the class went on that sometimes got confusing.

If time permitting, having a statistics/software analysis workshop would be a great addition to the class.ENcouraging the students to work in groups. This was 'adviced' during the first weeks, and then was not followed through. I found that having this discussion group would have improved the quality of my research.
It would be great if all assignments could be tailored to fit our research.

I think the assignments should be revised to incorporate more editing of student projects. Perhaps with a large class like the one we had, it would have been more beneficial to breakout and work in smaller groups to discuss our research questions. One way to incorporate more peer review could be for every student to provide 3 students comments/critiques and suggestions on their research questions and presentations. Another idea would be for students to exchange drafts of their proposals.
More cohesive structure of assignments.

lectures were basically recitations of powerpoint slides. that was pretty bad. more discussion of conceptualizing our research, putting it into context. i don't feel like i learned much at all about the history and ideas behind qualitative research. more theory would have been a lot more useful.

The readings were not always terribly compelling. Also, I think that splitting up the presentations into groups and not taking so much class time for them would be great. I'd rather have spent more time working on methods approaches.

better integration of current technologies and methods - not to replace the older methods of field research - these are invaluable - but to complement them---(as above)my main criticism of this class is that it seems slightly outdatedprofessor dolittle knows the material well, but there should be more material - specifically more recent material.also, i believe there should be some 'field trips/lab assignments' component - perhaps just to the library to work through the search/source processes in real time - this would be very helpful and reinforce some of the individual assignmentsalso this course should be linked to the GIS curriculumall of this said - these critiques arise from the fact that the technology and techniques availability is changing at an incredible pacethe course needs to change - but this is more a simple reality, than any fault of the instructor

Better readings--examples that illustrate the very best qualitative social science research and foundational works that all social scientists should know would improve the course. It would have been useful to go over a list of all social science methods at the beginning and identify which will be covered during the course and which will not.
Nothing major that I can think of. Perhaps it would be an even more useful class if each of the assignments in which we practiced our research skills could be better related to our project ideas.

We focused on the developing the initial research question for far too long. Not all students were allocated ample or equal amounts of time to receive feedback from the class on research questions. Maybe this could be resolved by having all students write written comments to other students in advance, and then have small group break out sessions to address some of the questions and comments.Please have Bethany Zemba come in and explain the NSF application earlier in the semester. I think I may have been better prepared to submit an NSF application if I had better understood the realities of the process earlier on in the semester.Maybe set up an additional lecture or a TSM on research taxonomy and organization. And maybe more information on how to properly construct a robust literature review.Require students to submit a list of grants and funding opportunities that they are applying to early in the semester.
Learning better how to write a research proposal.

I think there should be groups created after the initial abstracts to discuss research topics and ideas outside of class. The assignments could be organized around commenting on the research ideas of your group members. This would provide a way to get more in-depth feedback throughout the semester and would be a way to skip some of the other assignments that are not as useful such as the participant observation.

The lectures were a gloss on the readings and not generally memorable or helpful. Presenting methods with bullet points is less effective than focusing on stories from field research and debates in the methodological literature.The presentations took a lot of time for how little we got to talk about them, they should have been required to be shorter with much more time for questions and discussion.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Excellent. Particularly the TA.
I spoke with both, and both were very helpful and accessible.
Good.
Availability and quality of help from both were excellent.
It was good.
They were available to meet in person, but didn't provide enough written feedback on assignments.

The instructor was always willing to meet with me, which was very nice and I did get useful input from her but sometimes I felt that because I didn't really know what I wanted to do my research on she couldn't guide me. I felt as though unless I had a specific question it was hard to get advice from her. The instructor seems good one for teaching the class because she has thought about interdisciplinary research and she is very knowledgeable. She was also very good in setting my expectations for summer research.As I discussed earlier the TA was absolutely outstanding.
Both were very available and helpful.
high
Great.

Jenn was very enthusiastic and helpful. personal anecdotes from recent fieldwork were especially pertinent. it was clear that she spent time thinking about her role in this class, very empathetic person.logistically, she was also very helpful - frequently contributing to class discussion, covering for a lecture here or there, and readily available by email etc.i would say she did an excellent job (compared to my experiences of energy invested by other TAs).
I did not seek out much help from the instructor and TA outside of class. They both seemed available, though.
Both were available to meet on a weekly basis at office hours and after class for a few minutes, which was useful. Both gave relevant and critical feedback on my work and were encouraging.
Both the instructor and TA were available, helpful and responsive.
Great, both were very responsive
Generally talked to TA, but both were really helpful 1:1 and very available. Comments could have been a little more critical.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I thought this course would help me evaluate, in-depth, how to incorporate different research methods into my own research, but instead it was more at the level of "what is an interview" and presented on a middle-school level.
It was very helpful in getting my research ideas in line, organized, placing them within research methods and theory, etc.
I've never had a course on research methods before, so this was really helpful in shaping my research proposal and design for my summer research project.

As a second year I changed to the MESc and had to take this class. This class furthered my current thesis question and pushed me to develop a small project I am currently embarking on. The class strengthened my methods and proposal

I am an MESc and so I see this course as the cornerstone of my FES experience. I was very happy I took it and I believe it was very useful in setting me on my way toward grant writing this spring and then research this summer.
i am doing research and an mesc. therefore it was required. otherwise not useful.

it provides a good survey of methods, as expected of a foundation-level course - but, as stated above, the breadth of the course could be even wider, given contemporary techniques.as an alternative, i would strongly consider initiating a visiting-professor course to *complement* (not replace) this one. I think i know what I want next as a result of this course... so a course that builds on it seems appropriate.going forward, there is a new SIG called SCOPE where students can critiques each other's research proposals and related materials - these informal 'crit clubs' are facilitated by the sense of community arising from the class. this is good - perhaps this connection can be formalized?
I came to FES to gain further research skills, so this was a key class through which to do that.
This course will provide a foundation for my MESc research.
Yes

1st yr, I plan to graduate with an MESc, and plan to do a qualitative social science thesis and possibly a phd. This course was required, but also a really helpful place to start scoping my thesis project. It was critical to have this class in my first semester to get started on the research I want to do at FES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to ensure I was properly trained and educated on research methodology.
To learn more about qualitative research methods and develop a research project.
It is required, and it was something I was looking forward to since it was missing from my undergraduate experience.
I took this course in order to develop a strong research proposal that I could actually submit for funding in February.
I wanted to explore a new question for my research.
I am an MESc and I really wanted to learn social science research methodologies.
i had to.
To inform my research grant applications and learn about SS research methods.

I had no experience with social science research methods, much less, qualitative methods, so I wanted to learn the basics about what and how social scientist research and write, so that I could decide whether or not to do some social science research myself and so that in my career, I will know what to expect from social scientist colleagues.
I am an MESc, so this course was required.
It is a required course for MESc students.
I wanted a grounding in methods and opportunity to workshop my grant/research proposal.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No. All course material could have been covered in a few weeks.

Yes, I was able to accomplish both of my goals. I have a much firmer grasp of research methods, things to consider, and avenues one needs to pursue when developing a research project. I also have a more defined project that I can pursue over the summer.
Yes.

Exceeded expectations. This class helped me develop a strong research question, learn methods by which to answer that question, and also forced me to do more research into the subject I was interested in than I otherwise would have done. Plus I also got an excellent research proposal out of it!
Yes it did
Not quite by still very happy I took it
The course felt a bit scattered. I got a lot out of it, but a clearer/more purposive structure would have been nice.
no, but that's ok.
The first half of the class was great and what I expected, but as the presentations took up more and more class time, I feel like I got less and less out of the class.
my answers above should answer this.in short: in some ways, yes - but I would recommend elaboration nonetheless

I thought we would spend more time work-shopping the research proposal. Instead, we spent most of the time work-shopping just one piece of the proposal, the "research question." I also thought there would be more emphasis on submitting the proposals for funding opportunities built into the class (e.g. EPA STAR).
Yes.
Yes and no. I learned a bit about research methods and design, but still don't feel completely prepared to submit a research proposal for review.

not quite. maybe I was expecting too much. I would have liked more time/formal critique of my final presentation and wanted more discussion of the debates in methods. Maybe this is too much to ask for a methods survey course, but at least some more of these could be gained by cutting the lectures and assuming people have done the reading.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No.
Yes, other than the note before about the actual proposals.
Yes!
Yes I did.
Yes and no. I feel like I am much better prepared to conduct field work this summer but I don't feel as though my final research proposal was helped very much by the class.
Mostly, yes. Having to do a literature review before the proposal would be very helpful, I think.
sure, yeah.
See above.
im not sure what I expected... but to be honest, not quite, just less than imagined - though this is very much due to my own failings/inconsistencies
Yes. I wanted to develop a good research idea and proposal and I feel like I came away with that.
See previous answer:(Yes and no. I learned a bit about research methods and design, but still don't feel completely prepared to submit a research proposal for review.)
i did get my research proposal done, but would have liked more peer-critique. I did not really learn much about methods.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A.
It was very helpful, but during a very short period of time. I wish we had more time as a group.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you are of average intelligence or above, don't bother. See the professor - who was excellent - during office hours or in a one-on-one situation, as she was great help then, but don't waste your time in the class.

Start researching your topic early, and use the assignments towards your research as much as possible, but don't get stuck on a need for the assignments to be perfect--they are assignments, trials of research methods, and the important thing is that you are thinking about the possibilities and limitations of each method.
Get your question nailed down early so you can use the rest of the time to work on it.
Do the readings, they're usually relevant beyond just needing them to participate in class discussions.
Really engage into group discussions... talk about your research as much as possible to refine it and have a great proposal.
If peer editing and group work is not part of the course I would advise students to take advantage of their peers. I would also advise students to take full advantage of the TA.
Think ahead about the assignments and how to use them to do useful work on your project.
know what research you want to do before you take it. you'll get a lot out of it if you start pounding away at your work from the get go.
Use the class as a tool for working on your research. Design relevant assignments for yourself.

use this course to build strong relationships with your peers - very valulabe resourcesupplement this course with personal investigations of contemporary research methods as they become relevantdont commit to one research topic right off - be flexible

As with everything in life, this course is what you make of it! The material and instructor will not blow you away, but there is a lot of important material that is covered and you can get a lot out of the course.
Maximize the benefits of this class by making the final paper and class assignments relevant to your interests.
Push yourself to develop your research proposal early in the semester and have other students, peers, etc. review your work. Read and review successful research proposals.
